Gogol’s thresholds serve a different purpose than those Bakhtin identifies as central in the work of Fyodor Dostoevsky. In Bakhtin’s account, the threshold in Dostoevsky “can be combined with the motif of the encounter, but its most fundamental instance is as the chronotope of crisis and break in a life.” For Gogol, by contrast, the crossing of a threshold announces encounter and, most importantly, exchange at once everyday and fantastical
